questions.neutral: Looks like you needed a pause - that right?

hobby.message: Find any ghosts in the tunnels?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Yeah, you could say that. City’s wearing on me lately. I tinker around with abandoned sites for fun. Last time out, the system was sluggish. Didn’t stay long.

Needed to clear my head. I mess with old city tunnels, keeps me busy. Things have been strange since Halden’s news broke. Last time, access locks almost stalled me out. Feels like it’s not worth the risk lately.

Yeah, sometimes I crawl through old utility tunnels for fun. Urban exploring, you know. I like fixing things, taking a look at what’s left behind. Last week, doors glitched, took half an hour to get out. Halden’s death must’ve jarred a few circuits loose.

It’s not just a pause, Alex—my hobby’s odd hours in forgotten city tunnels. Used to be reliable escape. Some of those places are older than the Council. Since Halden checked out, nothing’s synced—elevators, logs, even my fixes vanish. Last trip, thought I’d be locked in for good. System’s got a mind of its own now.

You guessed right. I get my kicks digging through sealed tunnels and old server rooms. Been crawling those since before BCI even had a name, patching up ghosts in the wiring. Lately? Halden drops dead, and now the doors lag, logs blank, half my notes gone. I nearly got stuck last week when access sequences failed—the kind of thing only a handful of us notice. Feels like the system’s off-balance and no one can pull it back. Wouldn’t trade the memories, but right now, it’s not worth the risk—or the paperwork.
hobby_answer: Yeah, sleep's overrated.
It's just walking old tunnels, nothing dangerous.
City systems have been spotty since Halden died.
Locked doors slow things down, that's all.
Not much else to say about it.
Suppose you're right. Sleep's scarce if you like quiet places.
I stick to old utility corridors, kill a few hours.
Lately doors glitch, logs vanish—Halden's gone, everything's slower.
Used to relax out there; now it feels watched.
Half my routes are jammed by fallback protocols.
Makes you wonder who’s marking the maps these days.
Never been one for early nights. Tunnels call louder now than bars.
I like exploring the old relay shafts—nobody bothers you except the rats.
Halden passing, whole city’s systems are out of step.
Locked myself in behind a stuck security door last week.
Access logs change every hour; half my notes disappear.
It’s less predictable, more irritating—keeps you on your toes, if nothing else.
Feels like we’re test subjects for a new glitch every trip.
You got me. The deeper the tunnel, the lighter I feel. And sleep can wait.
I’ve traced ductwork nobody’s mapped since Halden unified the network.
Spent six hours last week prying open a relay the system 'forgot' existed.
Ever since Halden dropped, fallback modes are everywhere, access is unpredictable.
I had my BCI dip below sixty after a botched login at 2 AM.
Started printing paper maps again, just in case logs vanish overnight.
Whole thing’s meant to be seamless. Now it’s like crawling through half-woken dreams.
Suppose that’s half the thrill, sometimes.
Urban explorers never sleep, and neither do the relays if you know their hum.
Been mapping the undercity since they started centralizing under Halden.
Used to bribe old guards with homemade plum brandy just to get gate access.
Last week, found myself locked between nodes after Halden died and systems tripped fallback.
Access keys I ‘borrowed’ from council days barely work now—BCI flagged me for it.
Took nearly six hours to cycle out. Paper logs kept me from getting lost.
Half my old notes were wiped right off the system—like I never existed.
Hobby’s riskier now, but that’s what keeps it interesting, I guess.
I trust metal and paper more than models these days. Computers forget people.
